newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Guatemala names reformer as human rights watchdog.
newsitem.headline: Guatemala names reformer as human rights watchdog.

text.p: The Guatemalan Congress on Thursday named a new human rights ombudsman, a high-profile post in a country with one of the worst human rights records in the hemisphere.
Julio Arango, a former judge and prosecutor, won 69 of 79 votes to become Guatemala's top watchdog for human rights and government corruption.

On paper, the five-year position is a highly symbolic one, but those who have occupied it in the past have turned it into a bully pulpit, earning nicknames like "conscience of the nation" and "defender of the people."

The post of human rights ombudsman was created in the mid-1980s by the country's first civilian leader in three decades. Then-President Vinicio Cerezo was under international pressure to clean up the country's dismal human rights record.

Guatemala is emerging from a 36-year civil war between leftist guerrillas and powerful military. Its scorched-earth policies of the war years earned the wrath of human rights groups worldwide as many Indian villages were wiped off the map.
